awd_titl_txt: Classical and Quantum Aspects of Black Holes, Horizons and Asymptotic Symmetries
awd_abstract_narration:
Symmetries play a critical role in physics and astronomy. They are usually associated with conserved quantities that allow for a clearer picture of a physical system. Of particular interest to the research supported by this award are symmetries present at the horizon of black holes. These have potential implications for gravitational scattering experiments, gravitational memory measurements, astronomical measurements of spinning black holes and quantum black hole information. The objective of this project is to further investigate these symmetries and the role that they play in physical systems. 

In the last few years, Strominger and group have shown that the infinitely many symmetries at light-like infinity form one part of an exact triangular equivalence of three phenomena which recur ubiquitously across a wide variety of physical systems and have been separately studied for a half century -- the other two phenomena being memory and soft theorems. Soft theorems characterize the low energy behavior of physical systems and can be derived as the `Ward identities' of the infinite number of symmetries. The third corner -- memory -- turns out to be simply the Fourier transform of the soft theorems. This very simple triangular equivalence occurs in various instances in physics: QED, Yang-Mills theory, gravity, in any number of dimensions, with or without supersymmetry, with leading, subleading or subsubleading soft theorems in one corner. While several triangles have been filled out, most remain incomplete. Each instance of the triangle has its own special and fascinating features, which will be investigated in this project. More recently, the triangular structure was found to have profound implications for the famous black hole information puzzle, which will also be pursued. In another direction, general relativity implies that the dynamics of the near horizon region of extreme Kerr is governed by an infinite-dimensional emergent conformal symmetry. Precision black hole spectroscopy has now advanced to the stage where astronomers are beginning to observe the regions of spacetime governed by this conformal symmetry. This award will support a systematic exploration of potential observational consequences of the conformal symmetry.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we discovered some important long-overlooked properties of spacetime implied by, but hidden within the Einstein equation for the gravitational force. These have far-reaching consequences for a number of issues in gravitational physics which we have started and will continue to explore. These discoveries followed from the mathematical equivalence [1] we proved of two famous results in disparate fields from over half century ago: Weinberg’s so called soft-graviton theorem [2], which he derived using quantum field theory and the asymptotic symmetries [3] of Bondi, van der Burg, Metzner and Sachs. These are further equivalent to the gravitational memory effect [4], which might be measurable in upcoming gravity wave experiments.

One of the newly-understood properties is that the empty space vacuum is not as empty as it seems [5]. In fact, there is an infinite number of vacua which differ subtly at its boundaries and carry distinguishing features which we referred to as soft hair.

We looked specifically at how this affects the structure of black holes and the famous no-hair theorem [6], which states that black holes are featureless bald objects characterized only by their mass, charge and spin. We found, in contrast, that soft hair appears at the boundary of empty space where it meets the horizon of a black hole [7]. Mathematically, the no hair theorem is correct but it had been physically misinterpreted. This discovery invalidated Hawking’s famous 1975 argument [8] that black holes destroy information because it assumed the no-hair theorem in its misinterpreted form. Moreover, it suggests a new line of research into the infamous black hole information paradox - one of the great paradoxes of twentieth century physics.

In a separate research direction, we are applying our knowledge of symmetries of rapidly spinning black holes to make analytic predictions for observations at the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) or other astronomical observatories. This complements numerical analyses by the EHT team in revealing a qualitative signal behavior which would be nearly impossible to find with computer simulations.

In the last year, the PI was awarded the Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics in recognition of his work on black holes.

References

[1] T. He, V. Lysov, P. Mitra, and A. Strominger, “BMS supertranslations and Weinberg’s soft graviton theorem,” JHEP 05 (2015) 151, arXiv:1401.7026 [hep-th].

[2] S. Weinberg, “Infrared photons and gravitons,” Phys. Rev. 140, B516 (1965).

[3] H. Bondi, M. G. J. van der Burg and A. W. K. Metzner, “Gravitational Waves in General Relativity. 7. Waves from axisymmetric isolated systems,” Proc. Roy. Soc. Lond. A 269, 21 (1962). R. K. Sachs, “Gravitational Waves in General Relativity. 8. Waves in asymptotically flat space-time,"Proc. Roy. Soc. Lond. A 270, 103 (1962).

[4] A. Strominger and A. Zhiboedov, “Gravitational Memory, BMS Supertranslations and Soft Theorems,” JHEP 1601, 086 (2016) [arXiv:1411.5745 [hep-th]].

[5] A. Strominger, “On BMS Invariance of Gravitational Scattering,” JHEP 07 (2014) 152, arXiv:1312.2229 [hep-th].

[6] P. T. Chrusciel, J. Lopes Costa and M. Heusler, “Stationary Black Holes: Uniqueness and Beyond,” Living Rev. Rel. 15, 7 (2012) doi:10.12942/lrr-2012-7 [arXiv:1205.6112 [gr-qc]].

[7] S. W. Hawking, M. J. Perry and A. Strominger, “Soft Hair on Black Holes,” Phys. Rev. Lett. 116, no. 23, 231301 (2016) [arXiv:1601.00921 [hep-th]].

[8] S. W. Hawking, “Breakdown of Predictability in Gravitational Collapse,” Phys. Rev. D 14, 2460 (1976).
